p: NA is the second most abundant glycoprotein on the surface of influenza A and B viruses, and plays an essential role during virus replication by facilitating release of progeny virions (Fig. 1B) (Du et al. 2019). It is well known that NA antibodies can protect against infection of influenza viruses (Schulman et al. 1968; Murphy et al. 1972; Monto and Kendal 1973; Doyle et al. 2013; Wan et al. 2013; Wilson et al. 2016; Wohlbold et al. 2017), by preventing virus budding and egress from infected cells, as well as ADCC and CDC (Wan et al. 2013; Krammer and Palese 2015; Wohlbold et al. 2017). NA consists of 11 subtypes (N1 to N11), and a series of “broadly” cross-reactive mAbs of NA have been isolated (Wan et al. 2013; Wilson et al. 2016; Wohlbold et al. 2017; Chen et al. 2018). Of note, most of these cross-reactive NA mAbs are limited to recognize heterologous virus strains of the same NA subtype, suggesting existence of conserved subtype-specific NA epitopes (Wan et al. 2013; Wilson et al. 2016; Wohlbold et al. 2017; Chen et al. 2018).
